body: The failure in DistributedTestOpenJDK11 is GEODE-6613 which is a known flaky issue that is still open
@jmelchio

It may have been good to let the acceptance test and distributed test finish (especially since there was a new acceptance test)
My bad. :(
Timeout is not the problem in this case.

@bschuchardt (Not sure if my editing made this more readable or not) I'm actually a little worried about merging this change in. Without this change, LynnG encountered a failure which I think might occur more if we merge this in.

LynnG's analysis:

In this run we are expecting ForcedDisconnects, but they don't occur until after the hang is declared.

The difference between similar hangs and this is the appearance of these "Recursive call to appender" messages:
```
wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,554 Geode Failure Detection thread 6 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT
```
*** Test is dropping the network
```
wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/vm_9_locator_1_2_host2_13435.log: [info 2019/08/12 21:37:46.265 PDT <vm_9_thr_13_locator_1_2_host2_13435> tid=0x94] Dropping network connection from rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-46 to rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-1 and from rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-1 to rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-46
```
*** Here are the appender messages
```
wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,554 Geode Failure Detection thread 6 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT

wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,554 Geode Failure Detection thread 4 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT

wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,554 Geode Failure Detection thread 5 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT

wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,556 Geode Failure Detection thread 5 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT

wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,558 Geode Failure Detection thread 4 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT

wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/bgexec15919_14066.log: 2019-08-12 21:37:47,559 Geode Failure Detection thread 4 ERROR Recursive call to appender ALERT
```
*** network is dropped
```
wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/vm_9_locator_1_2_host2_13435.log: [info 2019/08/12 21:37:47.136 PDT <vm_9_thr_13_locator_1_2_host2_13435> tid=0x94] Dropped network connection from rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-46 to rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-1 and from rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-1 to rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-46
```
*** hang is declared
```
wan_bridgeNetworkPartition1-0812-213411/taskmaster_15326.log: [severe 2019/08/12 21:40:44.626 PDT <master_15326> tid=0x1] Result for vm_12_thr_16_wan1Lose_host1_14084: TASK[0] splitBrain.NetworkPartitionTest.HydraTask_doEntryOperations: HANG a client exceeded max result wait sec: 180
```
*** now we see ForcedDisconnects
```
[fatal 2019/08/12 21:40:57.826 PDT <unicast receiver,rs-FullRegression13040513a0i3large-hydra-client-46-43284> tid=0x24] Membership service failure: Membership coordinator 10.32.110.145(gemfire3_host1_14066:14066:locator)<ec><v2>:41000 has declared that a network partition has occurred
org.apache.geode.ForcedDisconnectException: Membership coordinator 10.32.110.145(gemfire3_host1_14066:14066:locator)<ec><v2>:41000 has declared that a network partition has occurred
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.mgr.GMSMembershipManager.forceDisconnect(GMSMembershipManager.java:2506)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.membership.GMSJoinLeave.forceDisconnect(GMSJoinLeave.java:1106)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.membership.GMSJoinLeave.processMessage(GMSJoinLeave.java:1481)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.messenger.JGroupsMessenger$JGroupsReceiver.receive(JGroupsMessenger.java:1328)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.messenger.JGroupsMessenger$JGroupsReceiver.receive(JGroupsMessenger.java:1266)
        at org.jgroups.JChannel.invokeCallback(JChannel.java:816)
        at org.jgroups.JChannel.up(JChannel.java:741)
        at org.jgroups.stack.ProtocolStack.up(ProtocolStack.java:1030)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.FRAG2.up(FRAG2.java:165)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.FlowControl.up(FlowControl.java:390)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.UNICAST3.deliverMessage(UNICAST3.java:1077)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.UNICAST3.handleDataReceived(UNICAST3.java:792)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.UNICAST3.up(UNICAST3.java:433)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.messenger.StatRecorder.up(StatRecorder.java:73)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.messenger.AddressManager.up(AddressManager.java:72)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.TP.passMessageUp(TP.java:1658)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.TP$SingleMessageHandler.run(TP.java:1876)
        at org.jgroups.util.DirectExecutor.execute(DirectExecutor.java:10)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.TP.handleSingleMessage(TP.java:1789)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.TP.receive(TP.java:1714)
        at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.membership.gms.messenger.Transport.receive(Transport.java:152)
        at org.jgroups.protocols.UDP$PacketReceiver.run(UDP.java:701)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
```
This is the same PR as #3935, except that the FileDescriptorMetrics binder tests are ignored on Windows. @kirklund @demery-pivotal @mhansonp

> Descriptive text looks fine. Alerts about updating the corresponding user guide passages may be helpful, but one wonders if they're truly necessary. Shouldn't developers _always_ check behavioral changes against the documentation? Never mind, silly question :)

I agree in an ideal world this shouldn't happen, but the truth is it already did (which prompted part of this PR).  Someone saw new dependencies were added which caused a test to fail, so they fixed the test but the documentation remained stale.  Any hints we can give to someone who is fixing a broken test to also fix the documentation doesn't hurt ;P.
Closing this PR to investigate potential for appender recursion more.
I defaulted to the interface and class name but don’t have a strong preference either way. PDX is likely more recognizable by customers.

@dschneider-pivotal please re-review. I changed the approach: instead of not expanding the attributes in `CreateRegionCommand`, I chose to expand it everywhere, including the `RegionConverter`. This is because I found the subsequent code kind of relying on the DataPolicy being set all the time in xml configuration objects. If we don't do this, we get NPE everywhere, so it's easier just to expand it.
@mcmellawatt please review and merge if you are happy

Hi @balesh2 , as I commented before, the way how putAll working is to try put entries and when it is not authorized it throws exception and go out. If we use the same logic for getAll we got this problem: in case we have List with some entries, and user didn't have a permission for one of them, when it try to get that entry, an exception will be thrown and go out with not trying to get other entries. 
Now it is created to only log this exception and continue to get other entries from list so user can see in logs which entries cannot get.
If we really want to get exception we can use putAll logic and go out, or keep it like it was to only log it. 
Any other idea?
@joeymcallister @davebarnes97

This PR is blocked by some sort of environment issue causing DistributedTestOpenJDK11 to fail and the Gradle daemon to die.

Based on google searches [2] [3], the cause might be either:

1) the distributed test job is out of swap space when the Tomcat/Jetty tests run

2) the /proc/sys/vm/overcommit_memory and /proc/sys/vm/overcommit_ratio may be misconfigured

I don't have sufficient concourse knowledge to attempt to fix or change either of the above two settings in our precheckin environment. Can someone please help me with this?

The failure:
```
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM warning: INFO: os::commit_memory(0x00007f74a4ba4000, 65536, 1) failed; error='Not enough space' (errno=12) 
[thread 26510 also had an error] 
```
[1] https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/builds/88240
[2] https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8216619
[3] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46801741/jvm-crashes-with-error-cannot-allocate-memory-errno-12

@agingade: I've replied to your comments, please let me know if you want me to make any changes 👍 .

Hi,

I did not work on this ticket for some time. Just to be clear, is the idea to update basicPut() method in AbstractRegionMap, with logic to retry if create fails?

BR
Solution is updated and added basic integration test. Do we need more tests(we can run existing tests with IPv6)?

Currently this code on an existing entry ends up going into AbstractRegionMap twice, once to see if it can do it as a create and when that fails it retries it as an update. The optimization requested is to do this by going into AbstractRegionMap once. I think this would involve modifications to AbstractRegionMap basicPut.

So far, this PR has had one nearly-GREEN precheckin after increasing memory for the DistributedTestOpenJDK11 job. The only failure was RestartOfMemberDistributedTest  (GEODE-7118) which does not reproduce.

**fixed alerts:**

* 4 for Non\-synchronized override of synchronized method
I will yet, add some concurrent tests
@agingade: can you have a quick look at my responses and let me know if you're okay with the changes so I can merge this?.

> What is calling getLocalSize at this time? Depending on what that is, this doesn't seem like the correct answer.
> 
> It seems like it would be better to prevent usage/escape of this method on an uninitialized TypeRegistry.

The `TypeRegistry` itself calls it. `TypeRegistryStatistics` calls it too. The other option is to add an `initialize` method to `TypeRegistryStatistics` and delay its registration of a stat supplier until after initialization of the the `TypeRegistry` is complete. 

I don't have skin it it either way. Logically if there is no region then there are no types so the size is 0. So even if something outside of stats called this method it will always get a correct answer rather than NPE. I can also see an argument for propagating the initialize method all the way up the object structure.

To clarify, it is likely only stats sampler that will get into this state. The construction of `TypeRegistry` is immediately followed by initialize before the new `TypeRegistry`. Though there is a time where `TypeRegistry` is assigned to the member on `GemFireCacheImpl`, and therefore accessible to other threads invoking on the cache, prior to `initialize`. The sources of `PeerTypeRegistration` seems to expect this in some cases because it does check for `null` region elsewhere. In that case it throws an exception that the registry failed to initialize.
Would it be better to defer the initialization of statistics to initialize then, to not let a reference to this escape the constructor?

It would prevent this particular NPE but anything else making calls to `getLocalSize` prior to the `initialize` method would be subject to the same issues. We could reduced that by not assigning the `TypeRegistry` to the member variable until after initialize. I feel like the safest fix is what I have were we account for the mutability of the object and that for some period of time the reference may be null and that logically the size of the collection is 0 when it is null. A hybrid of the two is acceptable too.

@mhansonp Can you mark this as ready for review?

The change looks fine to me. Just a couple questions to help provide context:

Why does it only target this one file in particular?

Is removing the Asserts an agreed upon decision in Geode at large?  I see some value in these as they may help differentiate what object was null in the case of an NPE and in other cases they explicitly guarantee some desired condition.  Just wondering what the main motivation is to remove them in this case?

Are there better naming options than `InternalMembershipManager`. Internal in this case provides detail around its packaging, which I don't think is important to put in the name of the class as its already in the fully qualified name via the package structure. Is there something else that distinguishes it from the parent interface that describes its purpose, rather than Internal?

Also, the comments in `InternalMembershipManager` should be updated to match the new name of the class.  Right now they still reference `MembershipManager`.
Can you share the **why** behind this change for some context? Under what circumstances would this jar not be included?

I share @prettyClouds concerns - how do we know this is really optional? Are we testing that somehow? IMO we should be getting *rid* of optional dependencies in geode-core in favor of having separate geode modules with the dependencies - like we've done with geode-lucene, geode-redis, etc.
@pivotal-jbarrett  Are you good with the  latest changes?

Regular geode transactions are cleaned up (similar to rollback) after time out.

This is Geode JTA transaction manager implementation which does not handle timed out global transaction correctly. Third part JTA transaction manager may handle this correctly.

This pull request **fixes 4 alerts** when merging 9fe7eb1e525121e9bfe12896881068952233de58 into 36ca311610d5b2a6950441cd75ce686f171b60c6 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-f9a7272e5edcd15fc77add965ddf618de2e01e2e)

**fixed alerts:**

* 4 for Non\-synchronized override of synchronized method
@jmelchio

Letting a reference to `this` escape to other threads is considered an unsafe practice in java, so I really think it would be a better fix to move the initialization of statistics to the initialize method in this case.

Here's a good public reference on why you shouldn't let `this` escape:
https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-jtp0618/index.html

> Why does it only target this one file in particular?

The scope is limited to files that showed an impact to function execution benchmarking.

> Is removing the Asserts an agreed upon decision in Geode at large? I see some value in these as they may help differentiate what object was null in the case of an NPE and in other cases they explicitly guarantee some desired condition. Just wondering what the main motivation is to remove them in this case?

Assertion have been discussed in the past as only a means to meaningfully reflect limits of a function, like asserting that parameters are correct. In these particular cases the asserts were not doing that. In fact for all the bucket null checks the assertion was guaranteed to always be true because bucket always had an allocated array associated with it. The others were simply checks on the internal state, again for which error handling or code prevented and the asserts were never false.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** and **fixes 2** when merging 2e3939908ba319f2d20d3208780a6d574de4f351 into 6cbd679755257123c4e35d27bf7eaf5648f3fe0c - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/geode/rev/pr-1e3b4379e5546b67cde60863601cf6442b038713)

* 1 for Dereferenced variable may be null

**fixed alerts:**

* 1 for Potential output resource leak
* 1 for Potential input resource leak

> @prettyClouds - Do you have a suggestion for a different name? Right now this interface has the methods that we don't want to be called from outside the membership package.

I looked at the method and don't really see a way to cohesively group the methods that InternalMembershipManager has that MembershipManager does not, but I don't have a lot of context here.

On second thought, though, maybe now that MembershipManager has a pretty specific set of methods it can be renamed to something more specific than `Manager` and `InternalMembershipManager` can keep the more vague name until the interface simplifies. Maybe `MembershipPool` or `Members` or just `Membership`

> Eventually we want to get rid of InternalMembershipManager - we pulled out the methods that we actually want to expose to MembershipManager, but we haven't managed to get rid of references to the remaining methods on InternalMembershipManager yet. At that point these other methods may be uneccessary, or we may move them to new interfaces based on what they are actually doing.

I think that if the goal is to remove it, it is less concerning. Maybe the name can include something that indicates we are phasing it out?

> BTW, Internal... is a pattern that is used in other parts of geode, see InternalCache, InternalRegion, etc.

Is it a pattern that we agreed to/agree with or one that just emerged and we wish it hadn't? As someone with little context, it doesn't add any value other than being different so I don't have a name collision.
@jmelchio

Hey @davebarnes97,
I reverted to a separate page just because it seems easier to find and read from a user's perspective (👍). The older approach had everything related to the `SELECT` statement in one single page, the new one contains a separate section with sub-sections per aggregate function, making easier to read the usage and limitations of each one.

Thanks for the clarification. With regard to ease of use, a follow-up: How did you arrive at the order in which the aggregate functions are presented? They could have been alphabetical (with AVG first). Is it based on frequency of use?

Hey @davebarnes97: I guess that's just a personal preference, but I tried to present them in order of "complexity" from _easy_ to _hard_.
The first functions (`MIN` and `MAX`) are the easiest to understand, that's why they're at the top. After that `COUNT` and `SUM`,  not much to say about them. `AVG` goes at the very end basically because it's a "complex" computation that "uses" other two previously seen concepts (to calculate the `average` we need to `sum` all matching records and divide the result by the amount - `count` - of matching results).
Makes sense?.

Yes, that makes sense. However, the order in which the topics are presented does not match the order in which they appear in your introductory sentence. I would like to suggest that you take advantage of Bookbinder's auto-generated page-local TofC capability. Simply remove the  class="no-quick-link" tags from the anchors, and you'll have a list of live links to follow at the top of the page. Just a suggestion. I will approve the PR without requiring this extra step.
Thanks @davebarnes97, will remove the `class="no-quick-link"` and try it out locally before pushing the changes again!.
@jmelchio

The dependency on `jetty-server` also pulls in a transitive dependency on `javax-servlet-api`. When running in a Spring Boot context, the presence of the servlet api implies that the application is a web application which will attempt to launch an embedded Tomcat server. This may not be what the user intended.
Please update your PR commits with properly formatted and descriptive commit messages. See https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/GEODE/Commit+Message+Format
